The carbines are the rarest type with only 4000 made over 130 years ago but a true Colonial model seems to be rarer as I have seen more carbines. These are the four types of Kropatscheks described in Rifles of the World: The artilery carbine, the short rifle, the long rifle and the "colonial" (the long rifle with a hand guard added to aid in controlling convection currents of the hot barrel in the tropics!). I have a group photo of all types if anyone is interested. The last Colonial model I saw for sale was in the UK and sold for $1100 recently also with a bayonet. (I have the listing as it was last month) This version is a regular infantry rifle, that went through a modest factory conversion in 1889 for tropical climates where heat was a problem. Though all Krops were originally made for Portugal, there were some groups that were sent to other nations a few years later. This rifle has beautiful original bluing on the receiver, and it is complete + without blemishes or scratches. Considering many rifles this age no longer have actual bluing, but a patina or faded away blue, this is superb + definitely the best + finest receiver I have seen anywhere or in photos. The barrel is in similar condition, it has original bluing with all metal surfaces shiny-smooth with fading/mottling only in the last inch or so towards the muzzle (See photos). This is from 1000s of times they were standing at attention for inspection with their hands on the barrel ends and nose caps. A good part of the barrel was protected by the handguard of this model, so it remains superbly blued beneath. The rear sight is the other difference from most other Krops and it is a combination multi-sight that underwent a modification in the late 1880s when smokeless powder took over. Super cool engineering for the 1880s, as all Krop sights have several "ranges", one standard, one when you flip it forward like some Carcanos and then a sliding part for long distances (up to 2200 meters on this model!) While I have seen one shot well at 1000 yards, 2200 is just crazy, but back then, they still used volley fire, where lines of soldiers would face off + fire at each other, many times at long distances. The other rear sight I have seen on some rifles was graduated to 2000 meters and from what I can find, and not 100% verified, when smokeless powder became popular, many had different sights installed when returned to the armory as the ballistics were different and the range longer. The Colonials should all have the 2200 meter sight + the handguard. The wood has clear and nice cartouche stampings + there are all manner of proof marks and stamps and numbers in the metal as well as the wood. The wood has handling and use marks but FAR less than most others and the wood is pretty darn smooth and extra-fine along the sides and bottom with the buttstock having more dings. The original cartouches are clear on both sides as are the serial numbers. The serial numbers on every small part all match the receiver, stock and barrel with only the bolt being different as mentioned above. This bolt action is known as the slickest of all military surplus rifles, as Steyr used skilled craftsmen with a lot of hand labor to make these. The bolt slides on tight rails and the action and cartridge lifter works like new. If you have never racked a bolt on a KAR88, or of course, a Kropatschek, it is amazing for an age before technology and power tools as they are ALL that nice. Just a solid + slick feeling you can feel, not describe and similar to the difference between a Mossberg 30-06 (nice) and a 700BDL 30-06 from the 1960s...not even close. Theres a tube magazine beneath the barrel and unlike the Vetterlis that used an elevator moving up and down, these used a "spoon" that arced up and down from the rear. Same as the Mauser 1871/84 which added Mr. Kropatschek's tube magazine + lifter to the Mauser 1871 to create Germany's 1ST repeating rifle. Only working the bolt and feeling these rifles can you appreciate how well they were made. By the way, the bore is beyond excellent. Since these used black powder cartridges, that is amazing as my Vetterlis and others from the era are usually corroded. The Portugese used this model in service from the 1880s until 1964!! which means these were racked and handled and cleaned and inspected regularly for over 80 years and explains the wear from hands on certain areas and also, a good reason why the bores are so nice. Ammo is available as I found a place that loads both black powder and smokeless rounds in 8x60 Krop though it has been a while since I contacted them. Original ammo turns up and unlike French ammo which are duds and hangfires, I have seen every report say 100% firing. This Colonial model includes a bayonet and scabbard and the bayonet has NEVER BEEN SHARPENED! It has its issued edge. Of course the number does not match the rifle as there is no way they would remain together through 80 years of service, importing and over 50 years floating around the surplus market. Most Kropatscheks remain in Portugal and they are also collected heavily in Europe and I had many inquiries and bids from South Africa and Australia for my others I sold. Besides the receiver and barrel, the other metal parts that were handled regularly have more wear...the triggerguard and bottom part where a hand would be, have patina rather than bluing. The barrel bands are better and of course, all have proof marks. The nose-cap at the end of the rifle is faded more than the rest as this and the barrel end is where they were handled the most during training, inspection and every day they were in use. I imagine there were 1000s of times a soldiers hand was on the muzzle end. The original rod is present as it is a part of the system that holds the rifle together. I removed the handguard CAREFULLY (if you crack or break it, there is close to ZERO chance of replacing it) and the wear marks from the clamps are clearly original. This rifle has had the magazine tube cleaned and the spring and follower are pristine. This is important as many have been ruined trying to improperly remove the tube and you do NOT want to crimp, crush or break this part. (there is a youtube video on making a tool to remove) This one is ready to go. The lifter and action is in a closed metal box that is possible to disassemble, but difficult. As this one has deep and dark bluing with ZERO corrosion, and all looks beautiful including screw heads that appear to have never been touched, I left it alone. This rifle looks even better below the wood than above it and you usually find the opposite. The barrel under the wood is like new, with deep glossy bluing and the action housing looks like it was made recently it is so nice. Many old rifles hide all of the corrosion and damage under there, but this old girl looks even better undressed...try that on a lady over 100 years old. This one is not a wall hanger if you choose to shoot it, as it has a perfect bore and functions perfectly. These were built to last, at a time when Steyr craftsmen built rifles and not a CNC machine. The bolt is beautiful with all appropriate crown proofs and the stock is serial number matched to the rifle. This one has something I have not seen, a small brass tag attached to the front barrel band with the number 19 engraved. This may be a rack number, unit number or something only on Colonial models as I have never seen one. Not sure about that part and no references I can find. I have over 30 photos of every angle, and the metal under the wood as well as the other parts and the bayonet. If interested, I will send more. This is an antique and needs no FFL. It is a longer and heavier package with the bayonet (or short sword as it is an 18 inch blade)and will ship ground for $38 if not local. If you want a regular shooter, in decent shape but well worn, there are plain rifles for less, though not that much less, and a carbine or other colonial will be more. If you like the less common models and the finer examples in your collection, this is about as good as it gets. Even a so-so condition carbine is usually priced higher than this one, but for the collector who wants something special, do not pass this up, as you will NOT see another one like it again.
